Award.AwardTitle: Students Travel Grant for the SSBSE Symposium

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: This grant provides travel funds to increase participation from US researchers in a new research community by funding student travel to the Symposium on Search-Based Software Engineering. Search-based software engineering is new paradigm for software engineering in which software is developed by searching for components and optimizing for functionality and nonfunctional properties within constraints, with the goal of automating software engineering. The goal is to encourage research in this area while providing important educational/training experiences for the students and helping to build the next generation of global researchers. The grant will pay attention to underrepresented groups and take into account economic considerations.

Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the project is bring together the growing North American and international search based software engineering (SBSE) community in a welcoming forum for discussion and dissemination, and to sustain the recent flourishing of interest in the field. The presented papers at the event addressed problems in the software engineering domain through the use of intelligent  computational search techniques. We particularly encouraged papers demonstrating novel search strategies or the application of SBSE techniques to new problems in software engineering. 

The grant supported travel for participants to attend the 8th IEEE Symposium on Search Based Software Engineering (SSBSE 2016), in Raleigh, North Carolina on October 2-10, 2016, which is the main event in the search based software engineering  area. It was an excellent opportunity for them to learn about the search based software engineering techniques and how optimization algorithms can be adapted to address large scale problems in testing, quality, evolution, requirements engineering, etc. The event provided participants, with papers accepted, a great feedback about their work, and will create/strengthen collaborations with leading researchers in SBSE and software engineering in general. This community building event provided the necessary training to the next generation of researchers (students) based on tutorials, keynote speakers, technical presentations, graduate students and challenges trackm etc.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/05/2017
Modified by: Marouane Kessentini
